greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle T(n,k) in which the n-th row lists in increasing order the Heinz numbers of all perfect partitions of n.
comment: A partition of n is perfect if it contains just one partition of every number less than n when repeated parts are regarded as indistinguishable.

The Heinz number of a partition p = [p_1, p_2, ..., p_r] is defined as Product(p_j-th prime, j=1...r) (concept used by _Alois P. Heinz_ in A215366 as an "encoding" of a partition). For example, for the partition [1, 1, 1, 4] we get 2*2*2*7 = 56. It is in the sequence because the partition [1,1,1,4] is perfect.

Number of terms in row n is A002033(n). As a matter of fact, so far the triangle has been constructed by selecting those A002033(n) entries from row n of A215366 which correspond to perfect partitions. Last term in row n is 2^n.
reference: J. Riordan, An Introduction to Combinatorial Analysis, Wiley, 1958, p 123.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Rows n = 0..500, flattened
example: 54 = 2*3*3*3 is in the sequence because the partition [1,2,2,2] is perfect.
24 = 2*2*2*3 is not in the sequence because the partition [1,1,1,2] is not perfect (1+1+1=1+2; it is complete).
maple: T:= proc(m) local b, ll, p;
b:= proc(n, l) `if`(n=1, p(l), seq(b(n/d, [l[], d])
mathematica: T[0] = {1}; T[m_] := Module[{b, ll, p}, p[l_List] := (ll = Append[ll, 2^(l[[1]]-1)*Product[Prime[Product[l[[j]], {j, 1, i-1}]]^(l[[i]]-1), {i, 2, Length[l]}]]; 1); b[n_, l_List] := If[n == 1, p[l], Table[b[n/d, Append[l, d]], {d, Divisors[n] // Rest}]]; ll = {}; b[m+1, {}]; Sort[ll] ]; Table[T[n], {n, 0, 20}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Jan 28 2016, after _Alois P. Heinz_ *)
results.author: _Emeric Deutsch_, Jun 07 2015
